text: Mya-Rose Craig has been a committed “twitcher” and “birder” since she was a young girl (“twitching” involves the pursuit of a specific ornithological species, “birding” is casual spotting). Most weekends she is out in the countryside enjoying the wildlife. But last week the 18-year-old environmental activist, who is British-Bangladeshi, was spotted herself.
Her memoir, titled Birdgirl and the subject of a 14-way auction among British publishers, is rumoured to have sold for more than £250,000.

“Writing about birds and the environment is something I’ve done for years, so I was amazed that there was so much interest,” she says. “But with everything that’s going on in the world right now, perhaps people really are rediscovering the beauty and necessity of the natural world.”
The
image: Craig aged 11 with a crimson rosella

text: A vicar who was selected as a Labour candidate at the last election but stood down when he was accused of sexual harassment has been sacked by the Church of England for adultery.

The Rev Steven Saxby, 49, who called himself the Red Rev, was nominated for the Cities of London and Westminster seat. He has now been removed from his role at St Barnabas Church in Walthamstow, east London.
In March last year Christine, his wife, said that she had discovered that he had an affair with an organist at the church in October 2018 and a four-year affair with an international pianist.

At the time she told the Daily Mail: âMy husband of 20 years had an affair during October of last year, which I just found out about last night. Unfortunately, it was not the first. The âother womanâ accidentally revealed information which led me to finding out that he had an affair for four years with a trusted friend and sometime member of our congregation.â

Mrs Saxby, who was living with her husband and four children in the vicarage at the time, added: âI know that you will be shocked as I am about this. Please pray for us. We are in quite a precarious situation now regarding our house and future. I am trying so hard but it is difficult to remain dignified when your life is falling apart. I want to rage. The storm is still unfolding and every day brings more revelations. There seems to be no end to the lies.â
In March this year he was suspended by the Church of England. He apologised at the time for the âmistakesâ he had made and any hurt caused.

Mr Saxby was to be Labourâs parliamentary candidate in the Cities of London and Westminster in February last year after he received support from the Unite union and the endorsement of John McDonnell, who was shadow chancellor of the exchequer. He also had the support of Jeremy Corbyn.

Critics questioned his suitability after a clip emerged of him speaking alongside George Galloway, the former MP, at a mosque in east London. Mr Saxby withdrew his candidacy after he was suspended by the Labour Party pending investigation of a complaint relating to sexual harassment. At the time he said that it was âa complaint I strongly refuteâ.

The central London seat, which includes the Houses of Parliament, was a key marginal at the election. It had been held by Mark Field, a Foreign Office minister who had been the Conservative MP since 2001. At the 2017 election his majority fell from 9,671 to 3,148 and he stood down last year after video emerged of him grabbing a Greenpeace activist during the chancellorâs Mansion House speech event. He said that he feared she was armed and later apologised. The police took no action.

At the election last year the Conservatives held the seat. Nickie Aiken beat Chuka Umunna, the former Labour minister who stood for the Lib Dems, into second place and Labourâs Gordon Nardell was third.
Last night a spokesman for the Diocese of Chelmsford said: âWe hold everyone affected by this situation in our prayers.â
Mr Saxby was approached for comment.
image: Steven Saxby with Talulah-Eve, a trans model, and Jeremy Corbyn

text: A German environmental foundation that has been given more than £17m by Gazprom, the Russian energy giant, has been accused of being a “puppet” funded by Moscow to circumvent American sanctions on the final stretch of a controversial pipeline carrying Russian natural gas to Germany.

The Climate and Environmental Protection Foundation was set up this month in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, the largely rural state in northeast Germany where the 764-mile Nord Stream II pipeline comes ashore.
It is the creation of Manuela Schwesig, the state’s Social Democratic premier, who is an ally of Gerhard Schröder, Germany’s former chancellor and chairman of Nord Stream II.
Schröder has been attacked by political opponents for his close relationship with Vladimir Putin, the Russian president, with whom he reached the Nord
image: A Russian pipe-laying vessel moored in north Germany alongside sections of the Nord Stream II pipeline

text: ★★☆☆☆I’d better start by confessing that I’ve never much cared for the stories of Dr Seuss. He may be one of the patron saints of children’s literature in the US, but his relentlessly convoluted, wibbly-wobbly verse never appealed to me as a child. I hardly ever read his tales to my sons either.

So I’m not exactly the target audience for the Old Vic’s live-streamed revival of David Greig and Charlie Fink’s musical version of the ecologically conscious tale, first published 50 years ago, about an eccentric creature trying to save an idyllic landscape from the ravages of industrialism. Most reviewers, however, had kind words for the 2015 premiere. Indeed the Old Vic’s artistic director, Matthew Warchus, describes The Lorax as “one of the

Joss Garman was one of the first to be arrested. Before dawn on a Monday in October 2007, the 22-year-old and 50 other environmental campaigners invaded Kingsnorth power station in Kent. Eon, which owned and operated the station, had applied for planning permission to build a coal-burning facility on the site — the first of a wave of new power stations planned for the country.

The strategy for the protest was simple: flood the site with so many activists that the security team could not halt them all, and shut down the station. “We stayed in a farmhouse in bunks the night before, got up at 3am and all got into minibuses,” Garman, now 35, recalls. “We climbed the fence and went through these dusty
image: From left: Alok Sharma; Isabella Tree; Sir David Attenborough; Rosamund Adoo-Kissi-Debrah; Chris Packham

text: The children tumble from the trees into the igarapé, or forest brook, sending up beads of water. Fingers of sunlight break through the patchwork-green canopy overhead, illuminating them. A cobalt-winged butterfly flits past, mesmerising in its brilliance.

Drying off quickly in the hot Amazon sun, the youngsters scramble up a muddy path to their village of Sawré Muybu, home to about 130 indigenous Munduruku people — one in a chain of Munduruku settlements that stretch along the Tapajos River in the northern Brazilian state of Para. One small girl wears a silvery marmoset on her head as if it were a hat. A boy clutches a pet coati with a long striped tail.
Under a thatched shelter behind the chief’s house, their parents sit
image: A mother and child at Sawré Muybu village

text: The last time members of the Makah tribe killed a whale their village in northwest Washington state erupted in celebrations while animal rights protesters and the operators of several whale-watching boats staged protests as the creature was dragged to the shore.

Now, after years in which further hunts have been held up by legal challenges, the tribe may be allowed to kill once again, upon the recommendation of a judge who found that it would have little impact on a populace of gray whales at least 21,000 strong.
“It’s thousands of years of tradition for us,” TJ Greene, chairman of the Makah Tribal Council, said. “Our oral history teaches us that [whaling] was given to us early in our history.”
The tribe’s reservation has only
image: Members of the Makah tribe last killed a gray whale in 1999
